review.title: Decision Maker using Coupled Incompressible-Fluid Cylinders
review.abstract: The multi-armed bandit problem (MBP) is the problem of finding, as accurately and quickly as possible, the most profitable option from a set of options that gives stochastic rewards by referring to past experiences. Inspired by fluctuated movements of a rigid body in a tug-of-war game, we formulated a unique search algorithm that we call the `tug-of-war (TOW) dynamics' for solving the MBP efficiently. The cognitive medium access, which refers to multi-user channel allocations in cognitive radio, can be interpreted as the competitive multi-armed bandit problem (CMBP); the problem is to determine the optimal strategy for allocating channels to users which yields maximum total rewards gained by all users. Here we show that it is possible to construct a physical device for solving the CMBP, which we call the `TOW Bombe', by exploiting the TOW dynamics existed in coupled incompressible-fluid cylinders. This analog computing device achieves the `socially-maximum' resource allocation that maximizes the total rewards in cognitive medium access without paying a huge computational cost that grows exponentially as a function of the problem size.

sections.heading: 2. THE TUG-OF-WAR BOMBE
sections.text: Known as the "tug-of-war (TOW) bomb," the 3-user (1, 2 and 3) and 5-channel (A, B, C, D and E) decision-making device is shown in Figure 3. Two types of incompressible fluid (red and blue) are filled in coupled cylinders; the red (bottom) fluid deals with "user decision-making," while the blue (top) one handles "user interaction," each user's channel selection in each iteration is determined by the height of a green adjuster (a liquid surface), and the highest channel is selected. As the movements of red and blue adjusters stabilize to achieve balance, the "tug-of-war" principle in red keeps fluid for each user. In other words, when one interface goes up, other four interfaces fall down, and efficient channel selections are achieved.

sections.heading: 3. RESULTS
sections.text: To show that the TOW bomb certainly avoids the Nash equilibrium and regularly achieves an overall optimization, we consider a case where (PA, PB, PC, PD, PE) = (0.03, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.9) is a typical example. A portion of the reward tensor that has 125 (= 53) elements is described as follows for the sake of simplicity; only matrix elements for which each user does not choose low ranking A and B are shown (Tables 2, 3 and 4). For each matrix element, the reward probabilities are given in the order of users 1, 2 and 3. "The social maximum (SM)" is a state in which the maximum amount of the total reward sum is not chosen by all users. In this problem, the social maximum corresponds to a "segregation state" in which users choose three different machines (C, D, E) or the six segregation states indicated by the tables.

sections.heading: 4. CONCLUSION AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: We have shown that an analog decision instrument, the so-called TOW bomb, is physically implemented by using two types of incompressible fluid in coupled cylinders and achieving a general optimization of the channel assignment problem in cognitive radio. The TOW bomb enables the assignment problem for M users and N channels to be solved by repeating M-up-and-down operations of the fluid surfaces in the cylinders at each iteration; it does not require the calculation of exponentially many (O (NM)) evaluation values required when using a conventional digital computer. This suggests that an advantage of analog calculation persists even in today's digital age. The TOW bomb can also be implemented on the basis of quantum physics. In fact, the authors have used the optical energy transfer dynamics between quantum dots to construct the decision device based not only on our cognitive insights, but also on what we might expect to be a game problem [17].
